content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays a pathology slide with several sections of tissue stained with H&E. I can identify at least four, possibly five, distinct, basophilic (purple) structures that are consistent in appearance with lymph nodes. These lymph nodes are embedded in pale pink/white adipose (fatty) and connective tissue. The overall appearance is typical for a lymph node dissection from a colorectal cancer surgery specimen.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, I must examine not only the lymph nodes themselves but also the surrounding fatty tissue. This specific area, located in the adipose tissue between the uppermost lymph node and the one below it, is a critical region to scrutinize. I am systematically searching for several key prognostic features: 
1. **Extranodal Extension (ENE):** To see if tumor cells from the lymph node have broken through the capsule and are invading the surrounding fat.
2. **Tumor Deposits (TDs):** To look for discrete nodules of cancer in the fat that are separate from the primary tumor and have no residual lymph node tissue.
3. **Lymphovascular Invasion (LVI):** To identify tumor cells within blood or lymphatic vessels in the perinodal fat.
This systematic scan of the fat is essential for accurate cancer staging (N stage). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to systematically examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed on one of the lymph nodes located in the lower-left quadrant of the slide. I would zoom into this area as part of a comprehensive review of all submitted nodes. This specific node appears intact and densely cellular, requiring high-magnification assessment to scrutinize its architecture and cytology for any atypical cell clusters that would indicate metastatic cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this specific area on the lower right lymph node because its border appears irregular and ill-defined. The interface between the dense lymphoid tissue and the surrounding lighter-colored perinodal fat is not smooth. This is suspicious for either a large metastatic deposit replacing the normal lymph node architecture and/or extranodal extension (ENE), where the tumor has broken through the lymph node capsule to invade the surrounding fat. Examining this junction at high power is critical to confirm metastasis and assess for ENE. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my goal is to systematically examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The zoom box is placed on the periphery of the lymph node located in the upper right quadrant of the image. This area, specifically the subcapsular sinus, is a critical region to inspect because it is the initial site where metastatic cancer cells from an epithelial malignancy typically deposit after arriving via lymphatic drainage. Examining this area first is a high-yield step in screening the node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the lymph node in the upper right quadrant of the image. The reason for zooming into this specific area is that at low power, it appears architecturally abnormal. While much of the node is a uniform dark purple, this region looks lighter, more heterogeneous, and has a disrupted pattern. This is highly suspicious for a metastatic deposit, as tumor cells infiltrating a lymph node disrupt the normal architecture of lymphoid follicles and sinuses. The standard procedure is to screen all lymph nodes for such irregularities. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see predominantly mature adipose tissue, characterized by large, clear adipocytes. At the very top left, there is a dense infiltrate of small, dark, round cells, which are lymphocytes, representing the edge of the lymph node. I also see a few small blood vessels scattered throughout the fat. My impression is that this field shows the interface between the lymph node and the surrounding perinodal fat. In this specific view, I do not see any definite malignant glands, atypical cell clusters, or single tumor cells invading the fat. This appears to be a negative field, and I would continue to scan the surrounding area to confirm the absence of extranodal extension or tumor deposits.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image reveals a dense, diffuse population of small, round cells with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm, consistent with lymphocytes. The overall architecture is that of a lymph node, with preserved lymphoid tissue. I do not see any distinct nests of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or significant necrosis that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. There are some small blood vessels, some of which appear congested or hyalinized. My impression of this specific field is a reactive or normal lymph node, with no evidence of malignancy. I would proceed to scan the remainder of this node and all other nodes on the slide to confirm this finding.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, there is a clear demarcation between the dense, native lymphoid tissue (top of the image) and an infiltrating tumor (middle of the image). The tumor consists of irregular, back-to-back glands and small clusters of atypical epithelial cells with hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei. These neoplastic glands are infiltrating into the desmoplastic stroma and perinodal adipose tissue (bottom of the image). My impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma within the lymph node, and importantly, there is clear evidence of extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a dense and uniform population of small, mature-looking lymphocytes. There are several small blood vessels scattered throughout the lymphoid tissue. At the edge of the tissue, there is a fibrous capsule, adjacent adipose (fat) tissue, and black pigment, which is likely tattoo ink from a prior colonoscopy used to mark the tumor's location. Critically, there are no atypical cells, no glandular structures, and no clusters of malignant epithelial cells. My impression is that this is benign lymphoid tissue, and this specific field of view is negative for metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I can see the parenchyma of the lymph node. There is a clear infiltration by non-lymphoid cells. I see nests and irregular clusters of large, pleomorphic cells with abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and large, irregularly shaped, hyperchromatic to vesicular nuclei. These features are characteristic of malignant epithelial cells. These nests of carcinoma are disrupting the normal background of small, dark lymphocytes. There are also several dilated lymphatic or vascular channels, some of which are filled with blood or proteinaceous fluid. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma.
